title: 108_s2395
content: The Act is titled the "Theodore Roosevelt Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The Congress finds that Theodore Roosevelt, born on October 27, 1858, in New York City, had a distinguished career including serving as a representative in the New York State Assembly, Commissioner of the New York City Police Department, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Colonel of the Rough Riders during the Spanish-American War, and Governor of New York. Theodore Roosevelt, Governor of New York, became the 25th Vice-President in 1900 and the 26th President in 1901. He played a significant role in foreign affairs, making the US a world power and implementing reforms on labor, monopolies, and conservation. His commitment to conservation was influenced by his time as a rancher in North Dakota, leading to the establishment of numerous reserves and forests. During his presidency, Theodore Roosevelt placed nearly 230 million acres of land under public protection, including bird reserves, game preserves, national forests, national parks, and national monuments. He was posthumously awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for his bravery in the Spanish-American War, becoming the first President to receive this honor. In 1906, he also received the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in ending the Russo-Japanese War. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 silver coins with different designs, each limited to 500,000 coins. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender. The coins minted under this Act, containing 90% silver and 10% copper, will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Congress recommends striking the coins at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. Design Requirements for the coins minted under this Act include being emblematic of President Theodore Roosevelt's life and legacy, using designs by James Earle Fraser or Augustus Saint-Gaudens, and featuring Theodore Roosevelt as a Rough Rider on the $1 coins. The coins minted under this Act feature designs by James Earle Fraser and Augustus Saint-Gaudens. The obverse of the $1 coins bears the image of Theodore Roosevelt on horseback, based on Fraser's monumental bronze equestrian figure at the American Museum of Natural History. The reverse of the coins bears the eagle design from the $20 gold "double eagle" coin designed by Saint-Gaudens. The reverse of the coins minted under this Act shall bear a design based on James Earle Fraser's designs, depicting the crusader's flaming sword of righteousness and the "Big Stick" philosophy of President Roosevelt. It will also include the quotation "If I Must". The coins minted under this Act will bear a design based on James Earle Fraser's designs, featuring a flaming sword of righteousness and the "Big Stick" philosophy of President Roosevelt. The inscription on the coins will include the quotation "If I Must Choose Between Righteousness and Peace, I Choose Righteousness" from Roosevelt's work "Unwise Peace Treaties". The coins will also have inscriptions of the value, year, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by a citizens advisory committee. The curr_chunk states that the design for the coins will be reviewed by the citizens advisory committee established under section 5135 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary may issue coins in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2006, with sales possible before that date. Minting of coins under this Act will cease after December 31, 2006. The Secretary will sell coins minted under this Act at face value plus the cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. Coins can be sold individually or as sets. Surcharges may apply. The sales of coins minted under this Act require a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges received will be promptly paid to the Theodore Roosevelt Association for educational programs at Sagamore Hill National Historic Site and the Theodore Roosevelt Collection at Harvard University Library, as well as to the Theodore Roosevelt Medora Foundation. The surcharges received from the sales of coins minted under this Act will be used for educational programs at and around the Theodore Roosevelt National Park, including the construction of the Theodore Roosevelt Badlands Institute in North Dakota. The Theodore Roosevelt Association will receive the first $2,250,000 of surcharges, with any excess amounts divided between the Association and the Theodore Roosevelt Medora Foundation. Both organizations will be subject to audit requirements. The Roosevelt Medora Foundation will be subject to audit requirements under section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code for this Act.
